title: Impact of Stress on Health
content: Discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. Provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics. Discusses how our behavior is altered in the face of stress and how that not only has a pervasive effect on a personal level, but also on society as a whole in how we interact with each other.

title: Physiology of Stress Response
content: Explains the physiology of a stress response, and why it’s ingrained in our DNA. Discusses individual variation in the response to stress, and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: Social Rank and Personality Differences in Stress Response
content: Discusses how social rank and personality differences affect our stress response. Explores what’s happening in the brain when faced with stressful situations.

title: Role of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia. Discusses the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: Impact of Stress on Chronic Diseases
content: Discusses the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. Discusses impulsiveness, impaired judgement, and lack of empathy in times of stress.

title: Optimizing Brain Health
content: Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. The breakdown of the blood-brain barrier in neurodegenerative disease. An explanation for the observation that type 2 diabetes increases risk of Alzheimer’s disease. The role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration. Blood pressure: an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk. Possible mechanisms by which exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer’s disease. Possible brain benefits of sauna. The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk. How exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health. Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits. The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength. How to get enough of the right kind of protein in your diet. Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward.

title: Physiology of Stress Response
content: Stress causes changes in hormones in our body, the 2 most importantly include: Adrenaline and Glucocorticoids (human version called cortisol). Adrenaline in two seconds is handing guns out of the gun locker into whoever’s gonna defend you. Glucocorticoids are building the aircraft carriers that a year from now are gonna be essential. It does some of the slower components in the stress response, stretching out over minutes to hours. Adrenaline comes in immediately and triggers fight or flight for those initial few seconds. But 30 seconds later (or minutes later), then glucocorticoids come in. They increase vigilant thinking (in terms of smart evasion of the predator). The are bolstering the same process that epinephrine is boosting: Increasing glucose levels in your bloodstream. Going to storage sites throughout your body (liver, muscle) and breaking stuff down. Additionally, glucocorticoids shut down everything that’s not essential to surviving the next five minutes of this massive physical challenge. Digestion is impaired. Growth hormones are turned off. Reproduction is shut off.

title: Stress and Individual Variation
content: Too little stress can be harmful, but so can too much. The optimal amount of stress is referred to as stimulation. Individual variation plays a role in what each person's optimum amount of stress is. Hormone receptors also play a role in how people respond to stress. The level of receptors of the hormones, rather than the level of hormone itself, can be more consequential. Individual differences in levels of receptors, what version you have, how well that works, how avidly it holds onto the hormone, what it is then coupled with afterward downstream inside the cell, can be central to understanding individual differences.

title: Social Rank, Personality Differences and Stress Response
content: Social rank and personality differences can affect our stress response. In baboons, the higher rank in your troop, you have lower levels of glucocorticoid, lower blood pressure, etc. But what matters far more, is the contextual meaning of your rank. In humans, we also see a similar correlation to rank status and health. Personality differences can also make a huge impact on stress levels.

title: Brain Response to Stressful Situations
content: The amygdala in the brain is involved in fear, anxiety, and aggression. It is physically larger in size, has a higher metabolic rate and more electrophysiological activity in people who perceive neutral faces as threatening. Humans can use our cortex to think about something stressful, and this will go all the way down and affect our brainstem (heart rate increases, breathing increases).

title: Epigenetic Imprinting of Stress
content: If a mother is under great stress, she could imprint epigenetically into the child and alter many features about them as they would age (i.e. propensity to be depressed). Early experience can change the regulation of your genes (how easily you turn certain genes on/off in different parts of your body/brain).

title: Role of Stress on Memory
content: The hippocampus (important for memory and learning) is extremely sensitive to glucocorticoids. The optimal amount of glucocorticoids (something that is moderately “stressful” or stimulating), can be beneficial to your hippocampus. However, too much stress can do exactly the opposite to the hippocampus, decreasing oxygen and glucose delivery, making neurons less excitable, disconnecting synapses, causing the processes in neurons to shrivel, and blocking the birth of new neurons.

title: Impact of Socioeconomic Status on Stress Levels and Health
content: Socioeconomic differences, differences in absolute levels, differences in degrees of inequality within cultures and within communities are an enormous predictor of health. In the westernized world, there is a health/socioeconomic gradient. The poorer you are, the worse your health will be on the average (and when you get a disease, the more impactful it is).

title: Socioeconomic Status and Health
content: When a child is raised in a home low on the level of socioeconomic status that is a predictor of their likelihood of diabetes half a century later. With every step down starting from the ultra wealthy, there is statistically lower health as you go down every rung. Your socioeconomic status, your wealth, your objective measure of wealth, is indeed a predictor of your health. But it turns out at least as good of a predictor is your subjective socioeconomic status. When you look at people around you, how are you doing compared to other people? It turns out your subjective socioeconomic status is at least as good of a predictor of your health as is your objective socioeconomic status.

title: Stress and Health
content: It’s got very little to do with the material aspects of wealth or poverty, it’s got to do with the psychological aspects, it’s got to do with the stress. Social media is the amplifier to all amplifiers of this. You can’t go 10 minutes without looking at somebody who’s obviously better looking, obviously smarter, obviously richer, obviously having more fun. Social media and technology makes the vulnerable more damaged than in the past.

title: Managing Stress for Better Health
content: Of all the things that portend good health (nutrition, exercise, sleep, stress), stress is the most concerning. First off, you must practice regularly with set aside time (i.e. you can’t do your stress management on the weekends, or for the 30 seconds your on hold on the phone). In other words, like exercise you need hours per week of time set aside. Same with nutritional interventions as well as putting a premium on sleep. If you want to combat hypercortisolemia … “It ain’t a 20 minute a week thing.” 80/20 rule: Simply deciding that you are going to start doing something to manage your distress gets you 80% of the way there.

title: Genes and Emotional States
content: When you get to genetic influences on behavior and our internal lives, genes are important, but overwhelmingly these are genes that modify vulnerability to certain environments. The single most important gene is the serotonin transporter (targeted with SSRI/Prozac). The gene comes in a few different variants, one of which appears to make you more at risk for major depression.

title: Impact of Gene Variants and Stress on Depression and Aggression
content: There was no increase in risk having the bad variant. However, if coupled with a lot of childhood stress, there was about a 20x increase. The same childhood stressors to people without the “bad” gene variant had only a moderate increase in depression incidence. It turns out these different gene variants are regulated in different ways by glucocorticoids (so stress has an impact). Just having that variant doesn’t get you a higher risk of antisocial, violent behavior by age 25 unless it was coupled with childhood abuse growing up.

title: Effects of Sleep Deprivation on Cortisol Levels
content: When we are sleep deprived, our cortisol levels are elevated. An hour before you wake up, levels begin to rise, not for dealing with a stressor that has already commenced, but in preparation for having to get up and function. Not only is it bad not to get enough sleep, and not only is it bad if that insufficient sleep is fragmented, but the worst is if it’s fragmented unpredictably. If you have elevated glucocorticoid levels while you’re asleep, you have less delta sleep time (restorative sleep), you make less adenosine stores in your brain, and the sleep quality is going to be horrible.

title: Impact of Stress on Cancer
content: There’s a common perception that stress can play a very substantial role in the onset of cancer, in coming out of remission, and rates of tumor growth. However, the actual evidence is very, very minimal. Most human studies have too many confounding factors. When you induce a cancer and induce a lot of stress you likely will alter some other parameter (What it eats, how much it’s sleeps, the quality of its sleep).

title: Impact of Stress on Atherosclerosis, Dementia, Addiction, and Depression
content: The damage of hypercortisolemia and the accelerated stress response are probably most demonstrated in cardiovascular disease and atherosclerosis. Dementia is a disease of on a certain level, dopamine depletion. Depression is a disease of inability to feel pleasure and hedonia. Stress and glucocorticoids mess with the dopamine system. A messed up dopamine system predisposes us towards the two big psychiatric diseases: Addiction and Depression.

title: Impulsiveness, Impaired Judgement, and Lack of Empathy in Times of Stress
content: Stress will impact judgment, impulse control, executive function, long term planning, strategizing. During moments of extreme emotional arousal (especially aversive ones) we make terrible, terrible decisions that seem brilliant at the time. When we’re very stressed, it’s hard for the frontal cortex to do one of it’s harder jobs which is to take the view of the world from somebody else’s perspective. In both rats and humans, when you are stressed, you are less empathic towards strangers when they’re in pain.
